}} The 'Biu Emirate' is a traditional state based in Biu in Borno State,
Nigeria. Prior to 1920 it was referred to as the Biu Kingdom. The current ruler
is Maidalla Mustafa dan Aliyu(b. 1915) who became Mai Biu, also styled Kuthli,
in 1959. {{cite web
|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Nigeria_native.html |title=Traditional States
of Nigeria |publisher=World Statesmen.org |accessdate=2010-09-20}}

The rulers of Biu are numbered from Abdullahi, later known as Yamta-ra-Wala or
Yamta the Great, who established his rule about 1535. Montgomery-
Massingberd, Hugh (1980) "Biu" Burke's Royal Families of the World: Africa & the
Middle East (Volume 2 of Burke's royal families of the world) Burke's Peerage,
London, page 177, ISBN 0-85011-023-8 Around 1670, in the reign of Mari
Watila Tampta, it became known as a kingdom. {{cite web
|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/67284/Biu |publisher=EncyclopÃ¦dia
Britannica |title=Biu (Nigeria) |accessdate=2009-10-05}} The main ethnic
group is the Babur/Bura people, related to the Kanuri people. {{cite web |u-
rl=http://www.bornonigeria.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layou-
t=blog&id=37&Itemid=53&limitstart=4 |title=People And Languages of Borno State
|publisher=Borno State government |accessdate=2010-09-20}} The founder was
said to have come from elsewhere, captured the main town in the area, then
founded a new capital in Dlimbur, which is now an archaeological site. His
descendants formed two rival dynasties, one at Kogu and the other in nearby
Mandaragirau. {{cite book |page=73 |title=State formation and political
legitimacy, Volume 6: Political anthropology |author=Ronald Cohen, Judith Drick
Toland |publisher=Transaction Publishers |year=1988 |ISBN=0-88738-161-8}}

King Mari Watirwa (r. 1793â1838) of Kogu defeated Fulani invaders from the Gombe
Emirate to the west. In 1878 Mari Biya, became the first Bura king to rule from
Biu. The emir's palace is now situated in the town. With British
rule, Biu division was created in 1918. Mai Ari Dogo was acknowledged as the
first emir of Biu in 1920. The area became known as the Biu federation after
1957, when the districts of Shani and Askira were added to the emirate.

The Biu Emirate includes the Biu, Hawul, Kwaya Kusar and Bayo local government
areas. The Biu Emirate has by convention always produced the
Deputy Governor of Borno State, representing the south of the state. {{cite
web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201007120261.html |title=Borno 2011 - How
Power Will Shift |work=Leadership |author=Inuwa Bwala |date=11 July 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-
20}} Until recently, the Biu Emirate was one of three in Borno State, the
others being the Borno Emirate and the Dikwa Emirate. {{cite
web |url=http://www.onlinenigeria.com/links/bornoadv.asp |title=BORNO STATE |date=2003-01-
29 |work=Online Nigeria Daily News |accessdate=2010-09-20}} In March 2010
the Borno State Governor Ali Modu Sheriff split the old Dikwa Emirate into the
new Bama and Dikwa Emirates. {{cite web
|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201003290445.html |title=Kingmakers Crown New
Shehu of Dikwa |work=Daily Independent |author=Abdulkareem Haruna |date=28 March
2010 |accessdate=2010-09-20}} This triggered petitions from the people of
Hawul, Kwaya Kusar and Bayo to also have separate chiefdoms, which the governor
had stated he would do "if the need arises". {{cite web |url=http://www.sun-
day.dailytrust.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3121:beyond-the-
hype-over-new-emirates-in-borno&catid=7:comment-a-debate&Itemid=113
|title=Beyond the hype over new emirates in Borno |date=20 March 2010
|author=Inuwa Bwala |work=Sunday Trust |accessdate=2010-09-20}}
